âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle! Solid test case progression and engaging graphics. More analysis in comments.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Another great solo game by VizGhar, easy to understand and lots of tests/validators.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Perfect!

Good also for last validator Fedora!
Ready to go! Perfect game.

Ok for all except for last validator Fedora,
still try to find a solution.

Fixed
- don't show movement out of bounds
- currently played domino always above other dominoes (still behind "rules regions")

I believe game is ready to be released. I'll leave it here for a week

It looks like you have 20 test cases and only 18 validators. Is that okay for a solo game? It seems like regular puzzles force each test case to have a corresponding validator.

My Python finds solutions via brute force on all but 2 test cases and 2 validators. Are you able to solve all test cases and validators in any of your testing without any problem-space reduction? I definitely like that the last few test cases and validators make me do some some problem-space reduction.
Another super fun puzzle! There is a lot of opportunity for mutual exclusivity, but constructing all the me_requirements takes time creating a very interesting Algorithm X tradeoff.

Rules * Please add ":" after each of "==", "!=", ">x", "[0, 0]. Game input * Next rulesCount lines: Please change "(-1 in case of == or != rule)" to: â€¢ 1 â‰¤ ruleid â‰¤ rulesCount â€¢ rule is ==, !=, >, < or =. â€¢ ruleValue is a non-negative integer for >, < and = rules, and it is -1 for == and != rules. Output * Consider changing "dominoA" and "dominoB" to "a" and "b", as the current variable names sound like there are two dominoes. * Change the second paragraph to the following:
  • a and b are the number of pips on the two halves of a domino piece.
  • [x, y] is the position where the half with a is placed.
  • If orientation = 0 (horizontal), the half with b is placed at [x + 1, y].
  • If orientation = 1 (vertical), the half with b is placed at [x, y + 1].

Example: 5 3 2 4 1 places the domino with 5 and 3 pips so that the 5-pip half is at [2, 4] and the 3-pip half is at [2, 5].

Constraints * Please update the height/width constraints. They're current violated in the following cases: â€¢ Just do it (test) â€¢ Just do it (validator) â€¢ Snake (test) â€¢ Stick (validator) Cases * What's "Exupery"? * Rotate the board in Snake (test) so that its width = 1, similar to Stick (validator). After that, either flip the case upside down or use a different set of rules and dominoes. * There are very few cases with ">" and "!=" rules at the moment. Can more be added? Summary of existing cases: == 7 tests, 7 validators != 1 test, 1 validator > 2 tests, 2 validators < 5 tests, 5 validators = 12 tests, 12 validators I'll test the viewer and error messages later. Thanks.

The game has crashed. Please contact the author and enclose the following error:

java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: "1 = 2"
	at java.lang.NumberFormatException.forInputString(NumberFormatException.java:65)
	at java.lang.Integer.parseInt(Integer.java:580)
	at java.lang.Integer.parseInt(Integer.java:615)
	at com.codingame.game.Referee.init(Referee.kt:58)
	at com.codingame.gameengine.core.GameManager.start(GameManager.java:111)
	at com.codingame.gameengine.core.RefereeMain.start(RefereeMain.java:67)
	at com.codingame.gameengine.core.RefereeMain.main(RefereeMain.java:50)
Game is almost ready. Waiting for feedback :)
Testcases fixed. Have fun!
Fixed except for > and != testcases. I'll add some testcases later. TY
Does the current order of the cases look good to you?
I didn't need problem-space reduction just proper ordering. I'm placing dominoes to smallest areas first. This simple rule converged much faster.
For "Shoe" test, I tried to output 0 5 2 2 0 followed by 3 0 3 1 1. In the viewer, the later-played domino 3 0 appears *below* the earlier-played domino 0 5, rather than above it.
TY. Game is ready for approval
Fixed now and added those 2 testcases

It's generally not ideal for a case to serve as both a test and a validator, unless there's a strong justification. Creating a validator can be as simple as rotating the test. That may not be the best approach, but it does represent the minimal effort required.

Would @VizGhar create two new validators? Thanks.

Giraffe (test) and Chill cat (validator): Could you please update rules 1 and 9 so that they use > or < instead of ==? Alternatively, update the hints in the input board. I don't think == should apply to a single cell: it's not a useful hint.

(Optional) Some cases don't have the available dominoes sorted. Consider updating the input for consistency:
â€¢ Rotations (Test)
â€¢ Rotations (Validator)
â€¢ Train (Test)
â€¢ Locomotive (Validator)
â€¢ Giraffe (Test)
â€¢ Chill cat (Validator)

Thanks.
Oh missed that one. Will fix
Fixed - Tested - Submitted
Thank you for your quick action.

It's a bit unfortunate that the Rotations cases have to be amended, because they're supposed to showcase all the possible types of rotations. The cases have to be completely rewritten if we want to achieve the same purpose which maintaining the order of the input dominoes.
I shouldn't do any more games :D I didn't even though of the meaning of the testcase... Now there are all 3 rotations in both "Rotations" testcases
Anyways, there is debate in forum, that this puzzle should fall into HARD category. Let me/us now, what you think about increasing difficulty. I don't like it much for already released contributions

In my opinion,

1. It's always better to adjust things (difficulty or other matters) earlier rather than later, because fewer players have started solving the puzzle.

2. Adjusting the difficulty level after approval is fine, as it doesn't affect the task or the test cases. The core elements of the puzzle remain unchanged.

3. Difficulty changes should ideally be supported by statistics. However, given that only a small number of players have attempted this puzzle so far, the current data (success rate: 28%) might not yet be a reliable indicator.

4. Feedback from experienced players is always a valuable reference point.

5. Based on my usual rules of thumb (originally developed by @Wontonimo), I would probably rate this as Hard rather than Medium. In general, simple language features fall under Easy, while straightforward algorithms with limited complexity fit Medium.

That said, I hesitate to make a definitive recommendation here. Difficulty assessment is inherently subjective.

Oh, and there's another factor I sometimes use to gauge difficulty: how long it takes to solve. In general, I'd expect an Easy puzzle to take less than an hour, a Medium one a few hours at most, and a Hard one at least a full day.
I understand you're trying to solve the puzzle with plain recursive backtracking. If that succeeds, it can stay a Medium puzzle.
All Iâ€™ve done so far is write a solution. I havenâ€™t been able to make time to really look over the puzzle details. I will make that happen soon.
Have you had a chance to assess the cases? Thanks.

I have. This puzzle feels like the easy end of medium to me and I like that. A very small bit of optimization is needed to solve the toughest test cases and validators. @VizGhar and I took 2 different approaches to this optimization.

Test case difficulty ramps up pretty fast at the end. A case could be made for more test cases that smooth out this transition, but I've thought about it for a few days and I don't think that would make any difference in the puzzle experience.

The various rules are all well covered. '=' and '==' are seen much more often than the rest, but I don't see any issue with that.

Today's puzzles on the NY Times website are interesting. The "hard" level puzzle has 16 rules. The most rules seen here is 13. The NY Times also doesn't have any huge '=' groups.

I don't have any requests based on my analysis. The way it is now works for me.
Great, thanks for confirming! I myself also don't have further comments now, after the latest viewer fix and the addition of two validators.

Rules
* Please add ":" before "all cells must" and "the sum of" (5 times in total).

Cases
* What's "Exupery"?

* As mentioned last time, more cases with ">" and "!=" rules to be added.

Error messages
* Please change "â€¦doesn't exists" to "â€¦doesn't exist".

* Please change "integers dominoA dominoB" to "integers: a b" (notice the additional colon).

Referee
* I tried several outputs for "Just do it" (Test 1):

  â€¢ 2 3 0 0 1: Both messages "Invalid placement!" and "You won!" appeared, and I passed the caseâ€¦
  
  â€¢ 3 2 0 1 0 / 3 2 1 1 1 / 3 2 -1 0 1: I crashed the referee.

* I tried several outputs for "Rotations" (Test 2):

  â€¢ 3 2 0 0 1 twice: Got the message "Domino 3:2 doesn't exists" instead of "already played".
  
  â€¢Â 3 2 0 0 1 followed by 0 4 0 2 2 and nothing else: Got the message "Timeout!" only. Please add validation that orientation must be 0 or 1.

* For "Shoe" (Test 3):

  â€¢Â I tried printing 0 5 2 2 0, 3 0 2 1 1, 2 6 1 0 1 and 5 6 0 0 1 (in that order), but didn't get the "Invalid placement!" message.

Thanks.

Added testcases (total of 36)
= 108 occurences
> 17 occurences
< 20 occurences
== 35 occurences
!= 18 occurences

Rules and Referee fixed... I'll stress test Referee more tonight. Thanks again for such deep review.

Cases
* Please change "Trafic Lights" to "Traffic Lights".

Referee
* For "Rotations" (Test 2), I tried printing:

  â€¢ 3 2 0 0 1 twice, and got the message "Invalid placement!" instead of "already played".
  
  â€¢Â 3 2 0 0 1, 0 4 1 0 1, 0 4 0 2 0 and nothing else: Got no error messages.

Thanks.
Fixed... I still didn't stress-test my referee, but it looks like you already did that :) thank you very much

Glad to hear the fixes are in; I'll review them later. Just to clarify though: I didn't run systematic tests or cover all the test cases, so you should definitely give the referee a proper stress-test on your side. That way we can be sure nothing slips through ðŸ˜‰
